item.title: At 10 AM, Stock Options Soar as Retail Traders Unleash New Bots
item.description: When people talk about algorithmic traders, it evokes images of rooms full of math PhDs creating complex models that place huge trades in milliseconds after economic or earnings data is released. But now, it’s retail traders who are turning in droves to automated trading, building the kind of programs in their basements more associated with Wall Street banks than the Reddit thread r/wallstreetbets.
item.dc:creator: Bernard Goyder

media:content.media:description: S&P 500 Options Volume per Minute in 2025

item.title: High Risk and High Reward of Undersea Cables
item.description: Undersea cables carry 99% of the world's internet traffic, but how do these cables work, and are they worth the investment? Google’s first employee of its subsea unit, Jayne Stowell weighs in on how the company paved the way for hyperscalers to take over an industry once controlled by telecom giants. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Adani Energy Approves Raising $502 Million Via Share Sale
item.description: Billionaire Gautam Adani-controlled Adani Energy Solutions Ltd. approved raising 43 billion rupees ($502 million) via a stake sale.
item.dc:creator: Saikat Das

media:content.media:description: Gautam Adani, chairman of Adani Group, at the Kumbh Mela festival in Prayagraj, Uttar Pradesh, India, on Jan. 21, 2025.

item.title: OPEC+ Agrees on Third Oil Supply Surge Despite Russia’s Qualms
item.description: OPEC+ agreed to surge oil output for the third month in a row despite reservations from key member Russia, doubling down on a historic policy shift that has sent crude prices sinking.
item.dc:creator: Fiona MacDonald, Salma El Wardany, Nayla Razzouk, Grant Smith

item.title: How Long Will It Take to Fix Air Traffic Control?
item.description: How long will it take to address the outages plaguing our air traffic control system? Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University Air Traffic Management Program Coordinator Michael McCormick says it won't happen overnight, even as the Trump administration calls for an overhaul of the system. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Investing High in the Sky and Deep in the Ocean
item.description: This Wall Street Week explores problems with US air traffic control and looks at how undersea cables transmit the world's internet traffic.
item.dc:creator: David Westin

media:content.media:description: Sean Duffy, US secretary of transportation, during a House Appropriations Subcommittee on Transportation, and Housing and Urban Development, and Related Agencies hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, May 14, 2025. Duffy released a broad proposal to overhaul air traffic control last week, including the construction of new air traffic control centers while replacing old radars and other aging equipment.

item.title: Where the Stock Market Stands Now After a Wild Start to the Year
item.description: The stock market’s crazy first five months of 2025 have left Wall Street pros in a bit of a pickle.
item.dc:creator: Jess Menton

media:content.media:description: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Monday, May 19, 2025. A renewed wave of dip buying fueled a rebound in stocks from session lows, with traders trying to look past the US downgrade by Moody’s Ratings that has sent bond yields climbing and weakened the US dollar.

item.title: Adani Group Outlines Transport Network in Rebuild of Mumbai Slum
item.description: Adani Group plans to build a transportation network as part of the Dharavi redevelopment project in Mumbai that will house rail, road and airport transit facilities in a single location.
item.dc:creator: Advait Palepu, Saikat Das

media:content.media:description: Pranav Adani, director of Adani Enterprises Ltd., right, during a site visit to the Dharavi slum cluster in Mumbai, India, on Thursday, May 23, 2024. With a total market capitalization of $213 billion across 10 listed units alone, Adani Group controls vast swathes of the infrastructure that powers the nation’s growth and underpins the Asian expansion of companies from Apple Inc. to Amazon.com Inc.

item.title: Thailand’s $115 Billion Budget Clears First Parliamentary Hurdle
item.description: Thailand’s lower house of parliament backed a 3.78 trillion baht ($115 billion) annual budget as Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra’s multi-party coalition buried differences to support the spending plan.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana

media:content.media:description: This aerial photo shows vehicles driving along a highway between Khlong Toei slum (L) and high-rise buildings (R) in Bangkok on May 20, 2025.

item.title: China Auto Body Slams ‘Vicious Competition’ After BYD Price Cuts
item.description: China’s automobile industry association warned against “vicious competition,” days after BYD Co.’s price cuts fueled market concerns of a discount war that would further weigh on profits of electric carmakers.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Dingmin Zhang

media:content.media:description: Automobiles by BYD Co. outside the company's showroom in Coulsdon, UK, on Wednesday, May 28, 2025. BYD sold more electric vehicles in Europe than Tesla Inc. for the first time, overtaking the American brand that long led the continent’s EV segment. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: OPEC+ Supply Hike of 411,000 Barrels a Day is Main Scenario
item.description: An OPEC+ supply increase of 411,000 barrels a day in July is the main scenario for talks on Saturday, delegates said.
item.dc:creator: Grant Smith, Salma El Wardany

media:content.media:description: An oil drilling rig stands on one of the Causeway islands in the Manifa offshore oilfield, operated by Saudi Aramco, in Manifa, Saudi Arabia, on Wednesday, Oct. 3, 2018. Saudi Aramco aims to become a global refiner and chemical maker, seeking to profit from parts of the oil industry where demand is growing the fastest while also underpinning the kingdom’s economic diversification.

item.title: Charting the Global Economy: US GDP Falls on Larger Trade Hit
item.description: The US economy contracted slightly to start the year, largely reflecting a bigger tariff-related trade hit but also a larger downshift in household spending growth than first estimated.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle, Molly Smith

media:content.media:description: Cranes at the Port of Seattle behind a pier at the Waterfront in Seattle, Washington, US, on Wednesday, May 28, 2025. The Bureau of Economic Analysis is scheduled to release gross domestic product (GDP) figures on May 29.

item.title: India Confirms It Lost Fighter Jets in Recent Pakistan Conflict
item.description: Anil Chauhan, chief of defense staff of the Indian Armed Forces, spoke to Bloomberg's Haslinda Amin on Saturday while attending the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore. He called Pakistan’s claims that it shot down six Indian warplanes "absolutely incorrect,” though declined to say how many jets India lost. It's the first time the Indian military confirmed that it lost an unspecified number of fighter jets in clashes with Pakistan in May. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.description: A surprisingly difficult question.
item.dc:creator: Joe Weisenthal, Tracy Alloway

item.title: Anwar Says Malaysia 'Does Not Believe in Spheres of Influence'
item.description: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim says his country's "approach is one of active non-alignment" during a speech at the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore. "Stability does not come from carving up the map but from creating space for all," he tells the audience. (Source: Other)

item.title: China Bans All Poultry Imports From Brazil on Bird Flu Case
item.description: China has banned imports of all poultry products from Brazil after a bird flu outbreak was detected in the world’s top exporter, halting a trade worth more than $1 billion.
item.dc:creator: Hallie Gu

media:content.media:description: Earlier this month, Brazil halted chicken shipments to China and the EU for 60 days after the first case of avian influenza was reported

item.title: Philippine Casino Operator Hann Files IPO Prospectus, CEO Says
item.description: Philippine casino operator Hann Holdings Inc. has filed its prospectus for an initial public offering, Chief Executive Officer Dae Sik Han said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Jerome Morales, Cliff Harvey Venzon

media:content.media:description: Close-up of a pair of dice in a dice shaker. Photographer: Bloomberg Creative Photos/Bloomberg Creative Collection

item.title: How a Real-Time Livestock Trading Platform Works
item.description: On this episode of Bloomberg Next Africa, we take a deep dive into one of Bloomberg's 25 African Startups to Watch. SwiftVee is a real-time livestock trading platform. Jennifer Zabasajja is on location at one of the auctions to see how SwiftVee operates and how livestock and fintech meet. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Australia's Marles on Chinese Ownership of Port of Darwin
item.description: Australia's Deputy Prime Minister Richard Marles says the national government opposes Chinese ownership of the Port of Darwin, adding that Canberra isn’t under added pressure from the Trump administration to find a new buyer for the facility. He speaks with Bloomberg's Haslinda Amin on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Australia Says US Not Making Demands Over Chinese-Owned Port
item.description: Australia’s deputy prime minister said the national government has consistently opposed Chinese ownership of the Port of Darwin and isn’t under added pressure from the Trump administration to find a new buyer for the facility that is under increased scrutiny in Canberra.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao, Haslinda Amin, Ben Westcott

media:content.media:description: Richard Marles at the IISS Shangri-La Dialogue on May 31.

item.title: Hegseth Warns About China Threat, Urges Asian Allies to Boost Defense Spending
item.description: Speaking at the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore, US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth urged Washington's partners in Asia to increase defense spending and warned that "China seeks to become a hegemonic power" in the Indo-Pacific region. (Source: Other)

item.title: China’s Factory Activity Contraction Eases After Trade War Truce
item.description: China’s factory activity contracted at a slower rate in May after a reprieve in the tariff war with the US unclogged trade flows, even as weak domestic demand continues to weigh on the economy.
item.dc:creator: Lucille Liu

media:content.media:description: An employee on the body shop floor at the Zeekr Group Intelligent Factory in Ningbo, China, on Tuesday, April 29, 2025. Geely Automobile Holdings Ltd., China's fourth-ranked carmaker by market share, said last month that its AI-powered pilot system will be added to all of its brands, including Galaxy, Zeekr and Lynk&Co. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: Hadrian CEO Power Speaks on Re-Shoring High Skill Labor
item.description: Hadrian CEO Chris Power speaks at the Reagan National Economic Forum in California on re-industrialization and the re-shoring of high skill labor. He says you "have to automate" due to the lack of high skill laborers, but when automation and AI cannot do the job, a highly productive workforce is important. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Ascension Health Nears $3.9 Billion Deal for Amsurg Outpatient Centers
item.description: AmSurg, the ambulatory surgery company once part of Envision Healthcare, is in advanced talks to sell itself to Ascension Health for about $3.9 billion, according to people with knowledge of the matter.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Ronalds-Hannon, Michelle F Davis

media:content.media:description: JACKSONVILLE, FL - MARCH 14: A general view of the Ascension St. Vincent's Riverside Hospital on March 14, 2020 in Jacksonville, Florida. The World Health Organization (WHO) declared Coronavirus (COVID-19) a pandemic. (Photo by Cliff Hawkins/Getty Images) Photographer: Cliff Hawkins/Getty Images North America

item.title: Chinese Listing Spree Sparks Revival Hopes in Hong Kong Stocks
item.description: A wave of listings by Chinese companies is expected to reinvigorate trading activity in Hong Kong, with optimism growing that a robust pipeline of debuts will drive the broader stock market higher.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, April Ma, Mengchen Lu, John Cheng

item.title: Stripe CEO Collison Discusses Coding Advancements
item.description: Stripe co-founder and CEO Patrick Collison speaks at the Reagan National Economic Forum in California on coding advancements in recent history. He says "the reason for the stasis in the domain of atoms" cannot be blamed on the advancements in the world of bits, and that "it's not the internet's fault." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Air Traffic Control, Undersea Cables, International Students | Wall Street Week
item.description: This week, why fixing the US air traffic control system won't happen overnight and the Trump administration's plan to fix it. Plus, how hyperscalers have taken over the business of undersea cables to support our growing data needs. Later, a look into the role of international students in the educational industrial complex and innovation ecosystem. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Scholl Says AI Automation Can Bring Down Labor Cost
item.description: Boom Supersonic Founder & CEO Blake Scholl speaks at the Reagan National Economic Forum in California on labor costs and AI automation. He says that the US has a cost disadvantage in "everything that is attached to labor costs" and that we can't "subsidize and tariff" our way through that disadvantage. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Moody’s Cuts Brazil Outlook, Delivering Fiscal Warning to Lula
item.description: Moody’s Ratings lowered Brazil’s credit outlook to stable from positive, delivering a reproof to President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva’s government at a time when it is under increasing pressure to shore up the country’s fiscal situation.
item.dc:creator: Vinicius Andrade, Giovanna Bellotti Azevedo, Martha Viotti Beck
